Assuming that both players are dealt two random cards each, the probability of one player making quads on the flop is approximately 0.17%, or 1 in 594. The probability of the other player also making quads on the flop is the same.

If neither player makes quads on the turn, the probability of one of them making quads on the river is approximately 1.38%, or 1 in 72.5. The probability of the other player also making quads on the river is the same.

So, the probability of both players making quads on the river is approximately (0.0138)^2, or 0.00019044, or about 1 in 5,253.

Therefore, the overall probability of both players making quads in a heads-up Texas Hold'em game, without assuming pocket pairs, is the sum of these three probabilities, which is approximately 0.00020233, or about 1 in 4,941.
